Derek Wood
'''Jim Duggan'''
King Duggan |image = Hacksaw jim duggan 2011.PNG |caption= Duggan in October 2011 |height = {{height|foot=6|inch=3}} |weight = {{convert|270|lb|kg|abbr=on}} - {{convert|293|lb|kg|abbr=on}} |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1954|1|14}} |death_date = |birth_place = [[Glens Falls, New York]]{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/superstars/halloffame/inductees/hacksawjimduggan/| title=WWE Hall of Fame profile|publisher=WWE|accessdate=2011-03-29}} |resides = [[Lugoff, South Carolina]] |spouse = {{Marriage|Debra Duggan|1989}} |children = 2 |billed = Glens Falls, New York |trainer = [[Fritz Von Erich]] |debut = 1979 }} '''James Edward Duggan Jr.''' (born January 14, 1954),{{cite web |url= http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/profiles/j/jim-duggan.html |title=OWOW profile |publisher=Online World of Wrestling| accessdate=2008-03-22 }} better known by his [[ring name]] '''"Hacksaw" Jim Duggan''', is an American [[professional wrestler]]. He is signed to [[WWE]] on a Legends contract. His best-known [[List of professional wrestling terms#c|character]] is that of an American [[Patriotism|patriot]], which sees him use a [[lumber#Dimensional lumber|2x4]] length of wood as a weapon, the battle cry "Hooo!" and the [[U-S-A!|U-S-A! cheer]]. In the World Wrestling Federation (WWF, now known as WWE), Duggan was the winner of the first ever [[Royal Rumble#Match|Royal Rumble match]] in [[Royal Rumble (1988)|1988]]{{cite web |url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/royalrumble/history/1988114/mainevent/ |title='Hacksaw' Jim Duggan (spot No. 13) wins the 10-man Royal Rumble Match|publisher=WWE|accessdate=2008-03-22}} and in [[World Championship Wrestling]] (WCW), he was a [[List of WWE United States Champions|one time]] [[WWE United States Championship|United States Heavyweight Champion]]{{cite web |url=http://www.wwe.com/inside/titlehistory/unitedstates/|title=WWE United States Championship history|publisher=WWE|accessdate=2008-03-22}} and a [[List of WCW World Television Champions|one time (and the final)]] [[WCW World Television Championship|World Television Champion]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/wcw/wcw-tv.html|title=WCW World Television Championship history|publisher=The Great Hisa's Puroresu Dojo|accessdate=2008-03-22}} == Early life and career == Duggan grew up in [[Glens Falls, New York]], where he became a star [[athlete]] in [[Secondary school|high school]]. Duggan is of [[English people|English]] and [[Scottish people|Scottish]] ancestry. He was raised [[Presbyterian]]. His father was the [[Chief of police]] for the City of Glens Falls.{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0240913/bio |title=Jim Duggan (II)|publisher=Internet Movie Database|accessdate=2008-01-10}} Duggan was a [[Letterman (sports)|letterman]] in [[American football|football]], [[track and field athletics|track]], [[wrestling]], and [[basketball]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cagematch.de/?id=2&nr=1107|title=Cagematch profile}} In wrestling, Duggan won the New York State High School wrestling championship, unlimited weight class division – the first wrestler from Glens Falls to do so.{{Cite news|url=http://armdrag.com/matburn?event=8066&instance=9194|title=11th Annual NYSPHSAA Intersectional Wrestling Championships|access-date=2018-05-29}} Upon graduating from high school, he was recruited by [[Ohio State University]], but would instead choose to play [[College football|football]] at [[Southern Methodist University]] (SMU), where he was eventually voted team captain. Duggan earned his [[bachelor's degree]] in applied [[plant]] [[biology]]. After [[college]], Duggan was signed by the [[Atlanta Falcons]] of the [[National Football League]], but was released after being plagued by knee injuries. == Professional wrestling career == === Early career (1979-1982) === Duggan broke into the professional wrestling business thanks in large part to wrestler [[Fritz Von Erich]]. The two met while Duggan was on a recruiting trip to SMU. Duggan's first professional match was in 1979 against [[Gino Hernandez]]. Duggan began his career as a [[Heel (professional wrestling)|villain]]. Training at the Sportatorium in [[Dallas]], [[Texas]] as well as with [[Samoa]]n wrestling promoter [[Peter Maivia]], Duggan gained the attention of [[Vincent J. McMahon|Vince McMahon, Sr.]] and the [[World Wrestling Entertainment|World Wrestling Federation]] (WWF).{{cite web|url=http://www.accelerator3359.com/Wrestling/bios/hacksaw.html|title=Accelerator profile|publisher=Accelerator's Wrestling Rollercoaster|accessdate=2008-03-22}} After a brief stint with the WWF, Duggan began to work regularly for [[Georgia Championship Wrestling]]. During this time, Duggan was known by two in-ring aliases: in the [[United States]] as '''"Big" Jim Duggan''' and in [[Hawaii]] as '''The Convict''', a masked wrestler. After wrestling for a [[Birmingham, Alabama]]-based promotion, Duggan began wrestling in a promotion based in [[San Antonio]], [[Texas]] where he adopted his well-known '''"Hacksaw"''' [[nickname]]. === Mid-South Wrestling/Universal Wrestling Federation (1982–1986) === [[Image:Jim Duggan 2.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Duggan at a fan signing for wounded soldiers]] In 1982, Duggan made his debut in [[Universal Wrestling Federation (Bill Watts)|Mid-South Wrestling]]. Upon debuting as a [[Heel (professional wrestling)|heel]], and [[bounty hunter]] for [[Skandor Akbar]], Duggan soon became a member of the Rat Pack [[List of professional wrestling terms#S|faction]], alongside [[Ted DiBiase]], [[Matt Osborne|Matt Bourne]], and [[Jerry Stubbs|Mr. Olympia]].{{cite web|url=http://bodyslamming.com/other/hacksaw.html|title=Bodyslamming profile}} After newcomer [[Butch Reed|"Hacksaw" Butch Reed]] debuted within the promotion, Duggan and Reed had a [[Kayfabe|personal]] feud for a time over who would be the true "Hacksaw". The Rats also feuded with stars such as Reed, [[Magnum T.A.]] and the [[Junkyard Dog]]. During this time, Duggan interfered in a DiBiase/JYD match while wearing a gorilla suit during the Louisiana State Fair, causing JYD to lose a "[[Professional wrestling match types#Loser Leaves Town match|Loser Leaves Town]]" match in [[Shreveport]], [[Louisiana]]. After DiBiase aligned himself with [[Skandor Akbar]], Duggan refused to go along with him and became a [[Face (professional wrestling)|face]] for the first time in his career. At this time, Duggan began carrying his iconic 2x4. As a fan favorite, he won the [[UWF World Tag Team Championship|Mid-South Tag Team Championship]] with Magnum T.A. and later won the [[Mid-South North American Heavyweight Championship|North American Heavyweight Championship]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/us/midsouth/mswa/mswa-t.html|title=Mid-South Tag Team Championship history|publisher=The Great Hisa's Puroresu Dojo|accessdate=2008-03-22}}{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/us/midsouth/mids-na-h.html|title=Mid-South North American Heavyweight Championship history|publisher=The Great Hisa's Puroresu Dojo|accessdate=2008-03-22}} After the Mid-South North American title was retired when Mid-South became the [[Universal Wrestling Federation (Bill Watts)|Universal Wrestling Federation]] (UWF) in 1986, Duggan lost to [[Terry Gordy]] in a tournament final to determine the first [[UWF World Heavyweight Championship (Bill Watts)|UWF World Heavyweight Champion]]. Duggan then teamed up with [[Terry Taylor]] and won the [[UWF World Tag Team Championship]] for the second time.{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/us/midsouth/uwf/uwf-t.html|title=UWF World Tag Team Championship history|publisher=The Great Hisa's Puroresu Dojo|accessdate=2008-03-22}} After losing a [[Professional wrestling match types#Retirement match|Loser Leaves Town match]] to the [[One Man Gang]], Duggan left the UWF for the [[WWE|World Wrestling Federation]] (WWF). === World Wrestling Federation (1987 - 1993)=== ==== Early feuds (1987) ==== Duggan was signed to the WWF in January 1987, making his first major appearance with the WWF at [[WrestleMania III]], where he also made his [[pay-per-view]] debut. In the weeks preceding WrestleMania, Duggan began his first WWF [[Feud (professional wrestling)|feud]] with [[Nikolai Volkoff]]. At the event, he ran to ringside prior to a match between [[The Killer Bees (professional wrestling)|The Killer Bees]] and [[The Iron Sheik and Nikolai Volkoff]] and interrupted Volkoff's pre-match singing of the Russian national anthem.{{cite web|url=http://www.ndg.lv/lapa/wrestling/WWF%2085-1999/m87.htm|title=Wrestlemania III Results|accessdate=2008-03-22|quote="The Iron Sheik and Nikolai Volkoff vs. the Killer Bees". Duggan gets on the mic and says that Volkoff isn't going to sing that, because this is the land of the free and the home of the braves|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090921093241/http://www.ndg.lv/lapa/wrestling/WWF%2085-1999/m87.htm|archivedate=2009-09-21|df=}} Duggan had previously done this on TV matches leading up to the event. On May 26, 1987 Duggan and the Iron Sheik were arrested for DUI in New Jersey. Duggan was on the verge of release from the company, but was ultimately brought back in a lower spot on roster. Although he did not win any major titles in the promotion, for seven years he was a consistent fan favorite with his patriotic gimmick. His character was mainly comical, as he rarely was in major contention for titles. His first major WWF match was at the first-ever [[Survivor Series]] pay-per-view in [[Survivor Series (1987)|1987]], when he participated in the first [[Survivor Series#Survivor Series matches|Survivor Series match]] and was a member of the winning team.{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/survivorseries/history/1987/results/ |title=Survivor Series 1987 results |publisher=WWE |accessdate=2008-03-22 |quote=Hacksaw Jim Duggan, "Macho Man" Randy Savage, Ricky "The Dragon" Steamboat, Brutus "The Barber" Beefcake & Jake "The Snake" Roberts def. "King" Harley Race, Hercules, Honky Tonk Man, "Dangerous" Danny Davis & "Outlaw" Ron Bass |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080329070155/http://www.wwe.com/shows/survivorseries/history/1987/results/ |archivedate=2008-03-29 |df= }} ==== First Royal Rumble winner (1988–1989) ==== [[File:Hacksaw Jim Duggan.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Duggan in a WWF event]] By the late fall of 1987, Duggan received his first major [[Push (professional wrestling)|push]] since his return, being placed in a feud opposite [[Harley Race|"King" Harley Race]], who was using a monarch gimmick who sneered at wrestlers he thought were below him. Duggan vowed he would never give in to Race's demands to bow to him, and during a televised confrontation, took Race's crown and cape, though Race would later get them back.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}} At the [[Slammy Award#1987 Slammy Awards|1987 Slammy Awards]], where Duggan presented the nominees for "Best Ring Apparel," an on-stage shoving match between him and the winner (Race), a wild brawl broke out between the two, going backstage and eventually reaching back to the main stage before interrupting another award presentation and [[Gorilla Monsoon]] stepping in to separate the two. Duggan eventually defeated Race several times in both televised and non-televised shows.{{cite web|url= http://www.thehistoryofwwe.com/88.htm|title=WWF results, 1988|publisher=The History of WWE|accessdate=May 18, 2015}} Duggan participated in the first-ever [[Royal Rumble#Match|Royal Rumble match]] in [[Royal Rumble (1988)|1988]], where he was the 13th of twenty entrants. He won the match after he last eliminated the One Man Gang.{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/royalrumble/history/1988114/results/|title=Royal Rumble 1988 official results|publisher=WWE|accessdate=2008-03-22|quote="Hacksaw" Jim Duggan last eliminates One Man Gang to win the Royal Rumble Match (20-man version)}} At [[WrestleMania IV]], he participated in a 14-man tournament for the vacant [[WWE Championship|WWF World Heavyweight Championship]], where he lost to [[Ted DiBiase]] in the first round after interference from [[André the Giant]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/wrestlemania/history/wm4/results/ |title=WrestleMania IV official results |publisher=WWE |accessdate=2008-03-24 |quote=WWE Championship Tournament: Round One Match - "Million Dollar Man" Ted DiBiase w/Virgil and André the Giant def. Hacksaw Jim Duggan |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110525165317/http://www.wwe.com/shows/wrestlemania/history/wm4/results/ |archivedate=2011-05-25 |df= }} Shortly after WrestleMania IV, Duggan -- upset that André cost him his match -- came to the ring during one of André's matches and challenged him; a feud erupted when André suddenly grabbed Duggan and began throttling him, before Duggan knocked André out with his 2x4 board. André generally came out the winner in their matches, usually by interference from André's manager [[Bobby Heenan]]. André also interfered in several of Duggan's matches against other wrestlers, including [[Hercules (wrestler)|Hercules]] on the April 30 [[Saturday Night's Main Event results#Saturday Night's Main Event XVI|edition]] of ''[[Saturday Night's Main Event]]''.{{cite web|url= http://www.wwe.com/shows/snme/history/1985to1992/april301988|title=Saturday Night's Main Event results - April 30, 1988|publisher=WWE|accessdate=2008-03-24|quote=Hacksaw Jim Duggan def. Hercules}} Duggan earned a shot at the [[WWE Intercontinental Championship|Intercontinental Heavyweight Championship]] against [[The Honky Tonk Man]] in July 1988, but Honky Tonk got himself disqualified, thus retaining the title.{{cite web|url=http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/results/wweppv/wrestlefest88.html|title=Wrestlefest results|publisher=Online World of Wrestling|accessdate=2008-03-24|quote=IC TITLE MATCH: "Hacksaw" Jim Duggan defeated Honky Tonk Man (Champion) by DQ}} Duggan then began displaying traits of an American patriot by feuding with several [[heel (professional wrestling)|foreign villains]] in the fall of 1988. He got involved in a feud with [[Dino Bravo]], and the two were on opposing sides as [[Jake Roberts|Jake "The Snake" Roberts]]' team fought André the Giant's at the [[Survivor Series (1988)|1988 Survivor Series]]. Duggan was disqualified after he used his 2x4 on Bravo.{{cite web|url=http://www.hoffco-inc.com/wwe/ppv/ppv/sur88.html|title=Survivor Series 1988 results|publisher=Hoffco-Inc|accessdate=2008-03-24|quote=Duggan was DQed at 6:48 for using his 2x4 on Bravo.}} Duggan's team eventually lost the match.{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/survivorseries/history/1988/results/|title=Survivor Series 1988 official results|publisher=WWE|accessdate=2008-03-24|quote=André the Giant, Dino Bravo, "Ravishing" Rick Rude, Harley Race & Mr. Perfect def. Hacksaw Jim Duggan, Jake "The Snake" Roberts, Scott Casey, Ken Patera & Tito Santana}} His next feud was with [[Russia]]n [[Jim Barrell|Boris Zhukov]], whom he defeated in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Flag match|flag match]] on the November 26 [[Saturday Night's Main Event results#Saturday Night's Main Event XVIII|edition]] of ''Saturday Night's Main Event''.{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/snme/history/1985to1992/nov261988|title=Saturday Night's Main Event results - November 26, 1988|publisher=WWE|accessdate=2008-03-24|quote=Flag Match: "Hacksaw" Jim Duggan def. Boris Zhukov}} He restarted his feud with Dino Bravo, and at the [[Royal Rumble (1989)|1989 Royal Rumble]], Duggan and [[The Hart Foundation#The Hart Foundation|The Hart Foundation]] ([[Bret Hart]] and [[Jim Neidhart]]) defeated Bravo and [[The Fabulous Rougeau Brothers]] ([[Jacques Rougeau|Jacques]] and [[Raymond Rougeau|Raymond]]) in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Series variations|two out of three falls match]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/royalrumble/history/1988115/results/|title=Royal Rumble 1989 official results|publisher=WWE|accessdate=2008-03-24|quote="Hacksaw" Jim Duggan & The Hart Foundation def. Dino Bravo & The Rougeau Bros. (best 2-out-of-3 falls)}} He was involved in a rivalry with [[Allen Coage|Bad News Brown]], which culminated in a match at [[WrestleMania V]] where both men fought to a no contest.{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/wrestlemania/history/wm5/results/ |title=WrestleMania V official results |publisher=WWE |accessdate=2008-03-24 |quote=Bad News Brown vs. Hacksaw Jim Duggan went to a no contest |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080319101108/http://www.wwe.com/shows/wrestlemania/history/wm5/results/ |archivedate=2008-03-19 |df= }} ==== American patriot (1989–1993) ==== In mid-1989, he started a feud with [[Tonga Fifita|King Haku]], who was awarded the crown on the July 9, 1988 edition of ''Superstars'' when Harley Race was forced to vacate the crown due to injuries sustained in a match against Hulk Hogan on the March 12, 1988 edition of ''Saturday Night's Main Event''. Duggan defeated Haku to win the crown and earn the title of "King of the WWF" on the May 13, 1989 edition of ''Superstars''. On the May 27 [[Saturday Night's Main Event results#Saturday Night's Main Event XXI|edition]] of ''Saturday Night's Main Event'', Duggan earned a shot at the Intercontinental Championship against [[Rick Rude|"Ravishing" Rick Rude]]. Duggan won the match by countout, and Rude retained the title, as a title cannot change hands via countout or disqualification.{{cite web|url= http://www.wwe.com/shows/snme/history/1985to1992/may271989|title=Saturday Night's Main Event results - May 27, 1989|publisher=WWE|accessdate=2008-03-24|quote=Intercontinental Championship Match: "Hacksaw" Jim Duggan def. "Ravishing" Rick Rude (champion) by count-out}} At [[SummerSlam (1989)|SummerSlam]], Duggan teamed with [[Demolition (professional wrestling)|Demolition]] ([[Bill Eadie|Ax]] and [[Barry Darsow|Smash]]) in a six-man tag team match and defeated André the Giant and [[The Twin Towers (professional wrestling)|The Twin Towers]] ([[One Man Gang|Akeem]] and [[Big Boss Man (wrestler)|The Big Bossman]]).{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/summerslam/history/1989/results/ |publisher=WWE |accessdate=2008-03-24 |title=SummerSlam 1989 official results |quote=Demolition & Hacksaw Jim Duggan def. André the Giant, Akeem & Big Boss Man |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080726112517/http://www.wwe.com/shows/summerslam/history/1989/results/ |archivedate=2008-07-26 |df= }} [[Image:Jim Duggan.jpg|thumb|200px|Duggan poses for the fans]] He eventually lost his crown to [[Randy Savage|"Macho Man" Randy Savage]], who began calling himself "Macho King", and started a feud with Savage. At [[Survivor Series (1989)|Survivor Series]], he captained a team dubbed "The 4x4's" against Savage's team, "The King's Court". Although Duggan eliminated [[Greg Valentine]] with his 3-Point Stance Clothesline, Duggan's team lost the match.{{cite web|url= http://www.wwe.com/shows/survivorseries/history/1989/results/|title=Survivor Series 1989 official results|publisher=WWE|accessdate=2008-03-24|quote=The King's Court: "Macho King" Randy Savage, Dino Bravo, Earthquake & Greg "The Hammer" Valentine def. The 4x4s: Hacksaw Jim Duggan, "Rugged" Ronnie Garvin, Hercules & Bret "Hit Man" Hart}} He faced Savage again on the January 27 [[Saturday Night's Main Event results#Saturday Night's Main Event XXV|edition]] of ''Saturday Night's Main Event''.{{cite web|url= http://www.wwe.com/shows/snme/history/1985to1992/jan271990|title=Saturday Night's Main Event results - January 27, 1990|publisher=WWE|accessdate=2008-03-25|quote=Randy "Macho Man" Savage def. "Hacksaw" Jim Duggan}} Duggan defeated another former rival, Dino Bravo at [[WrestleMania VI]].{{cite web|url= http://www.wwe.com/shows/wrestlemania/history/wm6/results/|title=WrestleMania VI official results|publisher=WWE|accessdate=2008-03-25|quote=Hacksaw Jim Duggan def. Dino Bravo w/Earthquake}} He began teaming with his former rival, Nikolai Volkoff and started a feud with [[The Orient Express]] ([[Pat Tanaka|Tanaka]] and [[Akio Sato (wrestler)|Sato]]), whom they beat at [[SummerSlam (1990)|SummerSlam]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/summerslam/history/1990/results/ |title=SummerSlam 1990 official results |publisher=WWE |accessdate=2008-03-25 |quote=Nikolai Volkoff & Hacksaw Jim Duggan def. The Orient Express |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080908212016/http://www.wwe.com/shows/summerslam/history/1990/results/ |archivedate=2008-09-08 |df= }} He began a short feud with [[WWE Championship|WWF World Heavyweight Champion]] [[Sgt. Slaughter]] and faced Slaughter for the title on the February 1 [[WWF The Main Event#The Main Event V|edition]] of ''[[WWF The Main Event|The Main Event]]''. Slaughter retained the title by getting himself disqualified.{{cite web|url= http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/results/snme/910201.html|title=The Main Event results - February 1, 1991|publisher=Online World of Wrestling|accessdate=2008-03-25|quote=WWF TITLE MATCH: Jim Duggan defeated Sgt. Slaughter (champion) w/General Adnan by disqualification}} In late 1991, he patched up things with Sgt. Slaughter, who had turned babyface, and the pair formed a [[tag team]]. At [[Survivor Series (1991)|Survivor Series]], the duo joined the [[Kerry Von Erich|Texas Tornado]] and [[Tito Santana]] in an elimination match to defeat a team led by [[The Iron Sheik|Col. Mustafa]].{{cite web|url= http://www.wwe.com/shows/survivorseries/history/1991/results/|title=Survivor Series 1991 official results|publisher=WWE|accessdate=2008-03-25|quote=Hacksaw Jim Duggan, Sgt. Slaughter, The Texas Tornado Kerry Von Erich & Tito Santana def. Col. Mustafa, The Berzerker, Skinner & Hercules}} On the February 8 [[Saturday Night's Main Event results#Saturday Night's Main Event XXX|edition]] of ''Saturday Night's Main Event'', Duggan and Slaughter defeated the [[Beverly Brothers]] ([[Mike Enos|Blake]] and [[Wayne Bloom|Beau]]).{{cite web|url= http://www.wwe.com/shows/snme/history/1985to1992/feb081992|title=Saturday Night's Main Event results - February 8, 1992|publisher=WWE|accessdate=2008-03-25|quote=Sgt. Slaughter & "Hacksaw" Jim Duggan def. the Beverly Brothers}} At [[WrestleMania VIII]], he teamed up with [[Mike Jones (wrestler)|Virgil]], Sgt. Slaughter, and Big Bossman against [[The Nasty Boys]] ([[Jerry Sags]] and [[Brian Knobs]]), [[Jacques Rougeau|The Mountie]], and [[Barry Darsow|Repo Man]].{{cite web|url= http://www.wwe.com/shows/wrestlemania/history/wm8/results/|title=WrestleMania VIII official results|publisher=WWE|accessdate=2008-03-25|quote=Hacksaw Jim Duggan, Sgt. Slaughter, Virgil & Big Boss Man def. The Mountie, Repo Man & Nasty Boys w/ Jimmy Hart}} Slaughter eventually left active wrestling and Duggan continued to pursue his singles career again. In mid-1992, Duggan was moved to undercard status. In early 1993, he was involved in a feud with the then near 600 pound [[Yokozuna (wrestler)|Yokozuna]], who was the number one contender to the WWF Championship. [[Manager (professional wrestling)|Manager]] [[Mr. Fuji]] was bad mouthing America and Duggan challenged his protégé to a match. The match was promoted by claiming that no one had knocked Yokozuna off his feet, even though Yokozuna had fallen off his feet shortly before, during the 1993 Royal Rumble match. The stipulations to the match were if Duggan knocked Yokozuna off his feet, Duggan would win. On the February 6 edition of ''[[WWF Superstars of Wrestling|Superstars]]'', Duggan won the match after knocking Yokozuna down completely, but then was manhandled by the much bigger Yokozuna after the match and fell victim to four [[Professional wrestling aerial techniques#Seated senton|Banzai Drops]], sidelining Duggan for about four months. Duggan eventually returned to television and started a feud with then-Intercontinental Champion [[Shawn Michaels]], challenging him for the title on the May 3 edition of ''[[WWE Raw|Monday Night Raw]]''. Michaels ran through the crowd, and retained the title by countout.{{cite web|url=http://www.otherarena.com/htm/cgi-bin/history.cgi?1993/raw050393 |title=WWF Raw: May 03, 1993 |publisher=The Other Arena |accessdate=2008-03-25 |quote=Hacksaw Jim Duggan v. Shawn Michaels for the Intercontinental Title. Shawn makes a hasty escape, and Duggan can't believe he only won by countout. |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030530105546/http://www.otherarena.com/htm/cgi-bin/history.cgi?1993%2Fraw050393 |archivedate=May 30, 2003 |deadurl=yes |df= }} On the next show, to prevent Michaels from pulling the stunt again, Duggan received a return bout in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Lumberjack match|lumberjack match]] which Michaels won on a disqualification. As Michaels and the lumberjacks brawled after the match, Duggan came to and cleared the ring with his 2-by-4.http://www.thehistoryofwwe.com/raw93.htm{{cite web|url=http://www.otherarena.com/htm/cgi-bin/history.cgi?1993/raw051093 |title=WWF Raw: May 10, 1993 |publisher=The Other Arena |accessdate=2008-03-25 |quote=Hacksaw Jim Duggan v. Shawn Michaels in a Lumberjack Match, and for the Intercontinental Title. Perfect comes in and wallops Michaels, inviting an instant DQ win for the champ. |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030530110024/http://www.otherarena.com/htm/cgi-bin/history.cgi?1993%2Fraw051093 |archivedate=May 30, 2003 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Duggan then competed in the [[King of the Ring (1993)|King of the Ring]] tournament, defeating [[Charles Wright (wrestler)|Papa Shango]] to qualify before losing to [[Bam Bam Bigelow]] in the quarterfinals. He continued to appear on WWF programming until the summer, when he left the company after losing several pre-[[Summerslam]] matches to Yokozuna. === World Championship Wrestling (1994 - 2001) === ====United States Heavyweight Champion (1994)==== After spending a year wrestling independents throughout the Northeast and a tour of Austria for [[Catch Wrestling Association]], Duggan signed a contract with [[World Championship Wrestling]] (WCW) in the summer of 1994. He debuted on the August 6 edition of ''[[WCW Saturday Night]]'', defeating [[Rip Rogers]]. A month later at [[Fall Brawl (1994)|Fall Brawl]], as a replacement for the injured [[Ricky Steamboat]], he defeated [[Stone Cold Steve Austin|Steve Austin]] in a [[List of professional wrestling terms#S|squash]] match lasting thirty-five seconds to win the [[WWE United States Championship|United States Heavyweight Championship]].{{cite web|url= http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/usa/wcw/fall.html#94|title=Fall Brawl 1994: WarGames results|publisher=Wrestling Supercards and Tournaments|accessdate=2008-03-26|quote=Jim Duggan pinned Steve Austin (0:35) to win the WCW U.S. Title}}{{cite web|url= http://www.wwe.com/inside/titlehistory/unitedstates/304454111311|title=Jim Duggan's first Dance Dance Revolution Championship reign|publisher=WWE|accessdate=2008-03-26}} After becoming champion, he quickly started a [[Feud (professional wrestling)|feud]] with Austin, and eventually defeated him in a title rematch at [[Halloween Havoc (1994)|Halloween Havoc]] by disqualification.{{cite web|url= http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/usa/wcw/havoc.html#94|title=Halloween Havoc 1994 results|publisher=Wrestling Supercards and Tournaments|accessdate=2008-03-26|quote=WCW U.S. Champ Jim Duggan beat Steve Austin via DQ.}} The two had a second title rematch on the November 16 [[Clash of the Champions#Clash of the Champions XXIX|edition]] of ''[[Clash of the Champions]]'', where Duggan retained the title again by disqualification.{{cite web|url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/usa/wcw/clash2.html#XXIX|title=Clash of the Champions XXIX results|publisher=Wrestling Supercards and Tournaments|accessdate=2008-03-26|quote=WCW U.S. Champ Jim Duggan beat Steve Austin via DQ|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080624035919/http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/usa/wcw/clash2.html#XXIX|archivedate=2008-06-24|df=}} Duggan's reign ended at [[Starrcade (1994)]], where he was defeated by [[Big Van Vader|Vader]].{{cite web|url= http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/usa/wcw/starrcad.html#94|title=Starrcade 1994: Triple Threat results|publisher=Wrestling Supercards and Tournaments|accessdate=2008-03-26|quote=Vader pinned Jim Duggan to win the WCW US Title.}} ==== Various feuds (1995–1999) ==== After he lost the U.S. title to Vader, Duggan moved to the mid-card division and began wrestling on ''[[WCW Saturday Night|Saturday Night]]''. He defeated [[Bunkhouse Buck]] at [[SuperBrawl V]].{{cite web|url= http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/usa/wcw/s-brawl.html#V|title=SuperBrawl V results|publisher=Wrestling Supercards and Tournaments|accessdate=2008-03-28|quote=Jim Duggan pinned Bunkhouse Buck}} He faced former WWF rival Meng (known as Haku in WWF) in a [[martial arts]] match at [[Uncensored (1995)|Uncensored]], which Meng won.{{cite web|url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/usa/wcw/uncensor.html#95|title=Uncensored 1995 results|publisher=Wrestling Supercards and Tournaments|accessdate=2008-03-28|quote=Meng pinned Jim Duggan in a "martial arts" match}} At [[The Great American Bash (1995)|The Great American Bash]], he defeated [[Craig Pittman|Sgt. Craig Pittman]] by disqualification in Pittman's pay-per-view debut.{{cite web|url= http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/usa/wcw/gabash.html#95|title=The Great American Bash 1995 results results|publisher=Wrestling Supercards and Tournaments|accessdate=2008-03-28|quote=Jim Duggan beat Craig Pittman via DQ}} At [[Bash at the Beach (1995)]], Duggan lost to [[Kamala (wrestler)|Kamala]].{{cite web|url= http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/usa/wcw/beach.html#95|title=Bash at the Beach 1995 results|publisher=Wrestling Supercards and Tournaments|accessdate=2008-03-28|quote=Kamala pinned Jim Duggan}} In late 1995, Duggan started a feud with [[Ray Traylor|Big Bubba Rogers]], which culminated in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Taped Fist match|Taped Fist match]] at [[World War 3 (1995)|World War 3]], which Rogers won. Duggan participated in the first-ever [[Battle royal (professional wrestling)#World War 3|three ring, 60 man battle royal]] for the vacant [[WCW World Heavyweight Championship|World Heavyweight Championship]], but was eliminated.{{cite web|url= http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/usa/wcw/ww3.html#95|title=World War 3 1995 results|publisher=Wrestling Supercards and Tournaments|accessdate=2008-03-28|quote=Big Bubba Rogers pinned Jim Duggan in a "taped fist" match. Randy Savage won a "three ring battle royal" to win the vacant WCW World Title.}} He fought [[Martin Ruane|Loch Ness]] to a [[Professional wrestling#Disqualification|double disqualification]] at a ''[[WCW Main Event|Main Event]]'' taping before [[SuperBrawl VI]].{{cite web|url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/usa/wcw/s-brawl.html#VI|title=SuperBrawl VI results|publisher=Wrestling Supercards and Tournaments|accessdate=2008-03-28|quote=''Jim Duggan beat Loch Ness via DQ''}} Duggan then started a short feud with [[Diamond Dallas Page]], to whom he lost in a Taped Fist match at [[Bash at the Beach (1996)|Bash at the Beach]].{{cite web|url= http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/usa/wcw/beach.html#96|title=Bash at the Beach 1996 results|publisher=Wrestling Supercards and Tournaments|accessdate=2008-03-28|quote=Diamond Dallas Page pinned Jim Duggan in a "taped fist" match}} At [[World War 3 (1996)|World War 3]], he unsuccessfully participated in a three ring 60 man battle royal to determine the #1 contender to the WCW World Heavyweight Championship.{{cite web|url= http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/usa/wcw/ww3.html#96|title=World War 3 1996 results|publisher=Wrestling Supercards and Tournaments|accessdate=2008-03-28|quote=The Giant won a "three ring battle royal"}} Duggan had no major pay-per-view matches for over two years before he disappeared in 1998 after he was diagnosed with [[kidney cancer]]. After successfully beating his cancer, Duggan returned to wrestling and replaced [[Buff Bagwell]] in a match against [[Alex Wright|Berlyn]] at [[Fall Brawl (1999)|Fall Brawl]], which Duggan lost.{{cite web|url= http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/usa/wcw/fall.html#99|title=Fall Brawl 1999 results|publisher=Wrestling Supercards and Tournaments|accessdate=2008-03-26|quote=Berlyn pinned Jim Duggan}} Soon after, Duggan became involved in a storyline where he became a [[janitor]] for WCW. Duggan then started a feud with the anti-American stable the [[Revolution (professional wrestling)|Revolution]] ([[Shane Douglas]], [[Dean Malenko]], [[Perry Saturn]], and [[Christie Wolf|Asya]]). At [[Starrcade (1999)]], he and his surprise partners, the newly reunited [[The Varsity Club|Varsity Club]] ([[Kevin Sullivan (wrestler)|Kevin Sullivan]], Mike Rotunda, and [[Rick Steiner]]), faced the Revolution in a losing effort after the Club turned on Duggan.{{cite web|url= http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/usa/wcw/starrcad.html#99|title=Starrcade 1999 results|publisher=Wrestling Supercards and Tournaments|accessdate=2008-03-28|quote=Shane Douglas, Dean Malenko, Perry Saturn, & Asya beat Jim Duggan, Kevin Sullivan, Mike Rotunda, & Rick Steiner}} As a result of losing, the next night on ''[[WCW Monday Nitro|Nitro]]'', Duggan was forced to denounce the U.S. flag but he refused to do so. In response, the Revolution attacked him and began beating him until [[The Filthy Animals]], who were also feuding with the Revolution, saved Duggan.{{cite web|url= http://www.ddtdigest.com/updates/1999123m.htm|title=WCW Monday Nitro - December 20th, 1999|publisher=DDT Digest|accessdate=2008-03-28|quote=Douglas orders Duggan to denounce the USA, and tear up the US flag. Duggan doesn't want to do it. The Revolution beats up Duggan. Filthy Animals music hits, and Kidman, Konnan, and Rey-Rey (on a crutch) hit the ring. They chase the Revolution from the ring}} ==== World Television Champion, Team Canada and departure (2000–2001) ==== {{main|Team Canada (WCW)|l1=Team Canada}} During this period, he found the [[WCW World Television Championship|World Television Championship]] in a [[Waste container|trash can]], which had been thrown away by the previous champion [[Scott Hall (wrestler)|Scott Hall]] earlier and claimed it for himself. He would make title defenses exclusively on ''Saturday Night'', and remained champion until the title was deactivated. After WCW was [[Reboot (fiction)|rebooted]] and the [[New World Order (professional wrestling)|nWo storyline]] ended, it was replaced by two new factions in WCW called [[The Millionaire's Club]] and [[the New Blood]], which began feuding with one another. The Millionaire's Club consisted of veterans and the New Blood consisted of young wrestlers of the 1990s. Duggan joined the Millionaire's Club and helped them in their war against the New Blood. Near the end of his career in WCW, he became involved in more major storylines, including one that involved him becoming a villain by abandoning the patriotic gimmick for a short time to join [[Lance Storm]] and his [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Stable|faction]] [[Team Canada (WCW)|Team Canada]]. This angle began when Duggan started working with the [[Misfits In Action]] (MIA) but at [[Fall Brawl (2000)|Fall Brawl]], he turned on MIA's leader U.S. Champion [[Bill DeMott|General Rection]] during Rection's title defense against Team Canada's Lance Storm. Duggan was the [[Enforcer (professional wrestling)#R|special guest enforcer]] for the match, and helped Storm in winning the match. During this time Duggan shaved his trademark beard, didn't bring his trademark 2x4 to the ring, and sang "O Canada". At [[Halloween Havoc (2000)|Halloween Havoc]], Duggan and Storm teamed up against General Rection in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Handicap match|handicap match]] for Storm's U.S. Title. Duggan missed an attack on Rection, which led to Rection pinning Duggan to win the match.{{cite web|url= http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/usa/wcw/havoc.html#2000|title=Halloween Havoc 2000 results|publisher=Wrestling Supercards and Tournaments|accessdate=2008-03-29|quote=Gen. Rection beat Lance Storm & Jim Duggan in a "handicap" match to win the WCW U.S. Title when he pinned Duggan}} Duggan continued to unintentionally cost Team Canada many of their victories, but he helped Storm to defeat [[Ernest Miller|The Cat]] in a match at [[Starrcade (2000)|Starrcade]]. However, after the match, Team Canada turned on Duggan, who then began feuding with Team Canada, and at [[WCW Sin|Sin]] he was the [[Professional wrestling match types#Special referee|special guest referee]] in a Penalty Box match between Team Canada and the Filthy Animals. Despite Duggan's role as the referee, Team Canada won the match after Storm forced [[Billy Kidman|Kidman]] to submit.{{cite web|url=http://www.100megsfree4.com/wiawrestling/pages/wcw/wcwsin.htm|title=WCW Sin PPV Card|publisher=Wrestling Information Archive|accessdate=2008-03-29|quote=Penalty Box Match: Lance Storm, Elix Skipper, and Mike Awesome defeated The Filthy Animals (Konnan, Rey Misterio Jr., and Billy Kidman) when Storm made Kidman submit in a "penalty box" match. Jim Duggan was the special guest referee.|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080201011737/http://www.100megsfree4.com/wiawrestling/pages/wcw/wcwsin.htm|archivedate=2008-02-01|df=}} === Independent circuit and Total Nonstop Action Wrestling (2002–2005) === After WCW was purchased by the WWF in March 2001, Duggan began wrestling in the [[independent circuit]]. On December 5, 2002, Duggan defeated Krusher Kong at LWE Xplosion. On the March 12, 2003 pay-per-view of [[Total Nonstop Action Wrestling|NWA Total Nonstop Action]] (TNA), Duggan made a surprise appearance and defeated fellow WCW alum [[Mike Sanders (wrestler)|Mike Sanders]].{{cite web|url= http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/results/tna/030312.html|title=NWA:TNA PPV results - March 12, 2003|publisher=Online World of Wrestling|accessdate=2008-03-29|quote=MATCH: Jim Duggan pinned Mike Sanders with a very slow running clothesline}} Duggan made another appearance in TNA on October 29, where he lost to [[Jeff Jarrett]].{{cite web|url= http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/results/tna/031029.html|title=NWA:TNA PPV results - October 29, 2003|publisher=Online World of Wrestling|accessdate=2008-03-29|quote=Jeff Jarrett defeated "Hacksaw" Jim Duggan}} === Return to WWE (2005 - 2009)=== ==== Teaming with Eugene (2005–2006) ==== [[Image:Hacksaw-Jim-Duggan-Aussie-Flag,-RLA-Melb-10.11.2007.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Duggan waving an Australian flag during his ring entrance in Australia, 2007, with his 2x4 in the corner]] Duggan appeared on the October 3, 2005 edition of ''Raw'', dubbed "The Homecoming" along with several other WWF/E alumni. He and the other legends attacked [[Rob Conway]] after Conway came to the ring and insulted them.{{cite web|url= http://www.wwe.com/shows/raw/archive/10032005/|title=A Stunning Homecoming|publisher=WWE|date=2005-10-03|accessdate=2008-03-29}} He was also one of the "legends" available for fans to select to team with [[Nick Dinsmore|Eugene]] in a match at [[Taboo Tuesday (2005)|Taboo Tuesday]] to face the team of Conway and [[Travis Tomko|Tyson Tomko]] ([[Jimmy Snuka]] was chosen instead of Duggan).{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/cybersunday/history/2005/results/ |title=Taboo Tuesday 2005 official results |publisher=WWE |accessdate=2008-03-29 |quote=Jimmy Snuka and Eugene def. Rob Conway & Tyson Tomko; Final voting results for Eugene's partner: Jimmy Snuka 43% Jim Duggan 40% Kamala 17% |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080705175520/http://www.wwe.com/shows/cybersunday/history/2005/results/ |archivedate=2008-07-05 |df= }} He returned to WWE again after [[Royal Rumble (2006)|Royal Rumble]], with a message from [[John Cena]] to [[Amy Dumas|Lita]] after [[Adam Copeland|Edge]] lost the [[WWE Championship]]: "HOOOOO!"{{cite web|url=http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/results/raw/060206.html|title=RAW results - February 6, 2006|publisher=Online World of Wrestling|accessdate=2008-03-29|quote=Hacksaw Jim Duggan did his "Hoooooooooooo!"}} Duggan and Edge began a short feud with each other which culminated in a match that occurred two weeks later on ''Raw'', which Edge won after Lita provided a distraction.{{cite web|url= http://www.wwe.com/shows/raw/archive/02202006/|title="Big Time" Pedigree|publisher=WWE|date=2006-02-20|accessdate=2008-03-29|quote=Edge first speared his way to victory against "Hacksaw" Jim Duggan}} After feuding with Edge and Lita, he became mentor and tutor to Eugene and the two feuded with the [[Spirit Squad]]. He began working on ''[[WWE Heat|Heat]]'' but also made a few appearances on ''Raw'' with Eugene and [[The Highlanders (professional wrestling)|The Highlanders]]. On the November 6 edition of ''Raw'', Duggan and Eugene faced the Spirit Squad in a match with the stipulation that the losing team would disband and never team up again. After Duggan was caught off guard after the other Spirit Squad members interfered and then pinned for the win, Eugene snapped and attacked Duggan.{{cite web|first=Louie|last=Dee|url= http://www.wwe.com/shows/raw/archive/11062006/|title=Payback is a Dick|publisher=WWE|date=2006-11-06|accessdate=2008-03-29|quote=losing team must split up forever. Johnny pinned Duggan. After the match, however, Eugene seemingly snapped, blindsiding his mentor and attacking the Legend with his own 2x4.}} He started a feud with Eugene, and three weeks later, the two had a match with each other, which Eugene won.{{cite web|first=Louie|last=Dee|url= http://www.wwe.com/shows/raw/archive/11272006/|title=R-K-Anarchy|publisher=WWE|date=2006-11-27|accessdate=2008-03-29|quote=Eugene defeated former partner and mentor Hacksaw Jim Duggan}} ==== Various appearances (2007–2009) ==== At [[New Year's Revolution (2007)|New Year's Revolution]], Duggan teamed with [[Super Crazy]] in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Gauntlet match|tag team turmoil match]] to determine the number one contenders to the [[World Tag Team Championship (WWE)|World Tag Team Championship]], in a losing effort.{{cite web|first=Andrew|last=Rote|url= http://www.wwe.com/shows/newyearsrevolution/matches/3929552/results/|title=Taking over the turmoil|publisher=WWE|date=2007-01-07|accessdate=2008-03-29|quote=Shad pinned Lance Cade after JTG hit him with a neck breaker in a match that pitted Cryme Tyme against Cade & Murdoch, the Highlanders, Super Crazy & Hacksaw Jim Duggan and the World's Greatest Tag Team}}{{cite web|url= http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/results/wweppv/newyearsrevolution07.html|title=New Year's Revolution 2007 results|publisher=Online World of Wrestling|accessdate=2008-03-29|quote=Cryme Tyme (Shad Gaspard & JTG) win the Tag Team Turmoil match!}} On the January 15 edition of ''Raw'', Duggan was dragged out by [[Rated-RKO]] (Edge and [[Randy Orton]]) and was beaten to a pulp.{{cite web|first=Noah |last=Starr |url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/raw/archive/01152007/ |title=Dx lives |publisher=WWE |date=2007-01-15|accessdate=2008-03-29|quote=The pair then dragged out a bloody "Hacksaw" Jim Duggan and let the Raw locker room know that if anyone else tried to interfere in their match, they would suffer the same fate. Naughty Nick Doehring then landed a ruthless Con-chair-to on Duggan}} Edge and Orton feared Duggan would help out Shawn Michaels in a handicap match and wanted to set an example for anyone else backstage that wished to do the same. On the March 5 edition of ''Raw'', he faced [[Chris Mordetzky|Chris Masters]] in a Masterlock Challenge, but was unable to break the hold.{{cite web|first=Noah|last=Starr|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/raw/archive/03052007/|title=A stunning revelation|publisher=WWE|date=2007-03-05|accessdate=2008-03-29|quote="Hacksaw" Jim Duggan failed to break Chris Masters' Master Lock in the Master Lock Challenge}} After months of wrestling on ''[[WWE Heat|Heat]]'', Duggan returned to ''Raw'' in July, teaming up with [[The Sandman (wrestler)|The Sandman]] and feuding with [[Carly Colón|Carlito]] and [[William Regal]]. This team was short lived as Duggan soon returned to ''Heat''{{cite web |first=Corey |last=Clayton |url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/raw/archive/07232007/ |title=One bad apple leads to Dominator destruction |publisher=WW E|date=2007-07-23|accessdate=2008-03-29}} and Sandman was soon released from his contract with WWE. On the August 6 edition of ''Raw'', Duggan was a contestant in the ''WWE Dating Game'', a parody of ''[[The Dating Game]]''. However, Duggan lost when [[Maria Kanellis|Maria]] chose [[Ron Simmons]].{{cite web |first=Corey |last=Clayton |url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/raw/archive/08062007/ |title=Checkmate: Booker beats Lawler in battle of kings |publisher=WWE |date=2007-08-06|accessdate=2008-03-29 |quote=WWE Diva Maria had the opportunity to choose between "Hacksaw" Jim Duggan, Ron Simmons, and Santino Marella. Maria chose Simmons to the delight of HSBC Arena crowd.}} On December 31, he lost a [[Royal Rumble (2008)|2008 Royal Rumble]] qualifying match to the returning [[Umaga (wrestler)|Umaga]].{{cite web|first=Greg|last=Adkins|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/raw/archive/12312007/|title=Promise kept|publisher=WWE|date=2007-12-31|accessdate=2008-03-29|quote=Umaga pounded Hacksaw to secure a spot at the Rumble}} After that, he began primarily appearing on ''Heat'' once again, defeating locals and teaming with Super Crazy. On the March 17 episode of ''Raw'', he participated in a 17-on-2 [[Professional wrestling match types#Handicap match|handicap]] [[Professional wrestling match types#Basic elimination matches|elimination tag team match]] as part of the 17 members of the ''Raw'' roster against [[John Cena]] and Randy Orton. After [[Cody Rhodes]] was eliminated, all the remaining ''Raw'' wrestlers attacked Cena and Orton, resulting in their disqualification.{{cite web|url=http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/results/raw/080317.html|title=RAW results - March 17, 2008|publisher=Online World of Wrestling|date=2008-03-17|accessdate=2008-04-01}} Duggan also took part in a 12-on-12 tag team preview match on the March 25 episode of ''[[ECW (WWE)|ECW]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/results/ecw-wwe/080325.html|title=ECW results - March 25, 2008|publisher=Online World of Wrestling|date=2008-03-25|accessdate=2008-04-01}} He competed 24-man battle royal was held just before [[WrestleMania XXIV]] aired to determine the #1 contender for an [[ECW World Heavyweight Championship|ECW Championship]] match. The match was eventually won by [[Glenn Jacobs|Kane]].{{cite web |url=http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/results/wweppv/wrestlemania24.html|title=WrestleMania 24 results|publisher=Online World of Wrestling|date=2008-03-30|accessdate=2008-04-01}} In the summer of 2008, Duggan started a short feud with [[Cody Rhodes]] and [[Ted DiBiase, Jr.|Ted DiBiase]] after Rhodes and DiBiase tried to convince Duggan to retire and let the young talent run the show. Soon after, Duggan would come out and announce that he would take Rhodes and DiBiase's advice and retire, but [[Jerry Lawler]] stopped him by convincing Duggan to stay. Duggan and Lawler then wrestled Rhodes and DiBiase on the August 25, 2008 edition of ''Raw'', but lost the match. On the October 20 edition of ''Raw'', Duggan confronted [[Santino Marella]] and [[Beth Phoenix]] during one of Marella's tirades against his three possible opponents at [[Cyber Sunday (2008)|Cyber Sunday]] ([[Roddy Piper]], [[Goldust]], and The Honky Tonk Man). Upset at being interrupted, Marella took off his clothes, getting ready to fight Duggan. Yet before a fight could begin, Marella instructed Phoenix to throw the clothes in Duggan's face, a move that temporarily distracted Duggan. Marella then [[Professional wrestling attacks#El Kabong|smashed a guitar]] over Duggan's head, ending the segment. Duggan would appear on ''Raw'''s 800th episode during [[Shoichi Funaki|Kung Fu Naki]]'s in-ring dance segment, which also involved various other members of the WWE roster. In 2009, Duggan appeared in the [[Royal Rumble (2009)|2009 Royal Rumble match]], entering at #29 and setting a record for the most years between Royal Rumble appearances. He was eliminated from the match by [[Big Show]]. On the August 10 episode of ''Raw'', Duggan made his final televised appearance as [[Sgt. Slaughter]] had him come out in place of [[Bret Hart]], due to the episode taking place in [[Canada]], when he introduced "The best there was, the best there is, and the best there ever will be" in order to mock the [[Canadians|Canadian]] fans. === Independent circuit (2009–present) === [[File:Hacksawjd.jpg|thumb|"Hacksaw" Duggan (right) poses with a fan at an independent show in 2013]] He then resumed wrestling on the [[independent circuit]]. He recently appeared on Pro Wrestling Ohio's "Wrestlelution 3" where he defeated "The Megastar" Marion Fontaine. On November 30, 2013, at WrestleCade 2013, Duggan defeated Daivari.{{Cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=101808|title=WrestleCade 2013 « Events Database « CAGEMATCH - The Internet Wrestling Database|last=Kreikenbohm|first=Philip|website=www.cagematch.net|access-date=2018-05-17}} He has signed on with Global Force Wrestling as a "legend" to help promote GFW events and tours. To promote the shows, GFW's [[Jeff Jarrett]] and Duggan have appeared at Dell Diamond on Thursday, May 28. In January 2016, Duggan appeared in an event for Modern Vintage Wrestling in Wilmington, North Carolina.{{cite web|url =http://www.pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/Other_News_4/article_84945.shtml#.VVJSpUZUNjB|title =GFW NEWS: WWE HOF'er joins Global Force as "legend," GFW sets Three Nights in Texas| publisher =PWTorch| accessdate = 2015-05-12}} On May 6, 2017, at AWF Head to the Edge, Duggan defeated Josh Price.{{cite web|title=AWF Head To The Edge|url=https://www.facebook.com/events/1826462847603220/|website=Facebook.com}} On June 1, 2018, Duggan wrestled for [[Impact Pro Wrestling]] at the [[Armageddon (convention)|Armageddon Expo]], held at the [[Horncastle Arena]] in [[Christchurch, New Zealand]]. He defeated Mr Burns to win the IPW Armageddon Cup. {{cite web|url =https://www.facebook.com/ImpactProWrestlingNZ/photos/a.10152145799176038.1073741834.20970521037/10157538348496038/?type=3&theate|title =Jim Duggan is the NEW Armageddon Expo Cup champion!| publisher =Impact Pro Wrestling| accessdate = 2018-07-06}} === Second return to WWE (2011–2012) === On April 2, 2011, Duggan was inducted into the [[WWE Hall of Fame]] by fellow inductee [[Ted DiBiase|"The Million Dollar Man" Ted DiBiase]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/superstars/halloffame/inductees/hacksawjimduggan/|title="Hacksaw" Jim Duggan|publisher=[[World Wrestling Entertainment]]|accessdate=2011-03-01}} Duggan returned to wrestling in WWE with an appearance at the 2012 [[Royal Rumble (2012)|Royal Rumble]] and entered the [[Royal Rumble#Match|Royal Rumble match]] as the #19 entrant and was eliminated by [[Cody Rhodes]].{{cite web|last=Caldwell|first=James|title=Caldwell's WWE Royal Rumble report 1/29: Ongoing "virtual time" coverage of live PPV - Rumble match, Punk-Ziggler, Cena-Kane, steel cage|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/wweppvs/article_57526.shtml|work=Pro Wrestling Torch|accessdate=30 January 2012}} On the February 3, 2012 episode of ''[[WWE SmackDown|SmackDown]]'', Duggan teamed with [[Santino Marella]] in a losing effort against the [[WWE Raw Tag Team Championship|WWE Tag Team Champions]] [[Primo and Epico]].{{cite web|title=WWE Smackdown Spoilers 2/3/12|url=http://expertscolumn.com/content/wwe-smackdown-spoilers-2312|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120204104852/http://expertscolumn.com/content/wwe-smackdown-spoilers-2312|archivedate=2012-02-04|df=}} On April 10, 2012, Duggan made an appearance on ''[[list of WWE SmackDown special episodes|SuperSmackDown LIVE: Blast from the Past]]'', where he lost to Hunico by disqualification. Later that year, he appeared on the July 3 ''[[The Great American Bash (2012)|SuperSmackDown LIVE: The Great American Bash]]'' event, teaming with [[Sgt. Slaughter]] and Santino Marella to face [[Hunico]], [[Camacho (wrestler)|Camacho]], and [[Drew McIntyre]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/smackdown/2012-07-03/results/page-7|title=United States Champion Santino Marella, Sgt. Slaughter & "Hacksaw" Jim Duggan def. Drew McIntyre, Hunico & Camacho|publisher=[[WWE]]|accessdate=2012-08-05|author=Michael Burdick}} == Other media == It was announced in February 2012 that Duggan would appear on a WWE original reality show called ''[[WWE Legends House]]''.{{cite web |url= http://www.pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/quicknews/article_58624.shtml#.U1CenlxfRuY |title=Cast revealed for WWE's Legends House; Video - Legends at dance class |date=February 28, 2012 |accessdate=April 17, 2014}} The show premiered on the [[WWE Network]] on April 17, 2014.{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestlingrumors.net/rowdy-roddy-piper-previews-wwe-legends-house/20747/ |title="Rowdy" Roddy Piper Previews "WWE Legends’ House" |date=April 16, 2014 |accessdate=April 17, 2014}} Duggan appears as himself in the film ''[[Pro Wrestlers vs Zombies]],'' in which he battles the undead with his 2x4.{{Citation|last=Knotts|first=Cody|title=Pro Wrestlers vs Zombies|date=2014-03-28|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2240046/|others=Roddy Piper, Jim Duggan, Matt Hardy|accessdate=2018-05-29}} In 1991 Duggan appeared in the ''[[Harry and the Hendersons (TV series)|Harry and the Henderson]]''{{'}}s TV series' 16th episode. Duggan appears in the sixth episode of the second season of ''[[GamesMaster]]'' in the UK, where he played WWF on the [[Super Nintendo]] against a boy he picked from the crowd, Hacksaw played as Macho Man Randy Savage and was beaten. Duggan also appeared in the season five finale of ''[[Duck Dynasty]]''.{{Cite news|url=https://www.aetv.com/shows/duck-dynasty/pictures/stand-by-mia/willie-introduces-hacksaw-jim-duggan|title=Stand By Mia - Duck Dynasty {{!}} A&E|work=A&E|access-date=2018-05-17|language=en}} Duggan and former WWF announcer [[Sean Mooney]] began recording a weekly podcast on the MLW Radio Network called ''Primetime with Hacksaw Jim Duggan and Sean Mooney''. Duggan left the podcast after 18 episodes leaving Mooney to host the show solo under the new title of ''Primetime with Sean Mooney''. In 2017, Duggan released the first issue of a biographical comic book miniseries through Squared Circle Comics, titled ''Hacksaw Jim Duggan''. In 2018, Duggan's trademark "Hooooo!" shout was used in Tuxedo and Zapp's song "Shy" in live performances and on TV appearances. == Personal life == [[File:Hacksaw Jim Duggan 2013.jpg|thumb|Duggan in 2013]] Duggan and his wife Debra have two daughters, Celia and Rebecca. He is a close friend of [[Willie Robertson]] who owns the Duck Commanders.{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldnews.com/entertainment/x1465803280/Sullivan-Column|title=Hacksaw Duggan talks about his career, life Wrestling legend thrilled to perform at PAL Hall in Fall River|accessdate=2011-05-01|publisher=Heraldnews.com|date=2009-03-18}} In 1987, Duggan and the Iron Sheik (Khosrow Vaziri) were pulled over by [[New Jersey]] [[police]] before a WWF event, suspecting Duggan of [[driving under the influence]]. After a search of the vehicle and the persons, police discovered that Duggan was under the influence of [[marijuana]] and [[alcohol (drug)|alcohol]], while Vaziri was high on [[cocaine]]. Small amounts of cocaine were also found in the vehicle. Duggan received a conditional release while Vaziri was placed on probation for a year. The scandal that erupted after two in-ring enemies were found drinking and doing drugs together led to the end of the angle, the Sheik's release, and Duggan's temporary departure from WWF. Duggan soon returned to wrestling.[http://www.wrestleview.com/info/faq/duggan.shtml WrestleView.com - Jim Duggan FAQ][http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/profiles/i/iron-sheik.html Online World of Wrestling][http://www.4w-wrestling.com/info/arrestfiles.shtml 4w-Online] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928181616/http://www.4w-wrestling.com/info/arrestfiles.shtml |date=2007-09-28 }}[http://www.wrestleinfo.com/IronSheik.html Iron Sheik Wrestleinfo] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150202011754/http://www.wrestleinfo.com/IronSheik.html |date=2015-02-02 }}[http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/2006/07/05/1669066.html CANOE - SLAM! Sports - Wrestling - RVD suspended 30 days] |title= On September 7, 1998, Duggan announced live on [[WCW Monday Nitro]] that he was diagnosed with [[kidney cancer]]. He underwent successful surgery, and because of the cancer was detected very early, no chemotherapy was needed. He wouldn't wrestle again until April 1999. In November 2013 Duggan started an IndieGoGo campaign to cover the cost repairing his torn rotator cuff. Funding closed December 2013 and raised $10,396; well over the goal of $6,500.{{Cite web|url=https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/hoooooo-support-an-american-hero#/|title=Hoooooo!! Support an American Hero|website=Indiegogo|language=en-US|access-date=2018-01-20}} Duggan is a supporter of Scottish football club [[Rangers F.C.]] and has also signed up as a life member to fans group [[Rangers First]].{{cite web|url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/archives/news/190905/ricksen-delight-at-cash-battle-victory/|title=Ricksen delight at cash battle victory|last=Archibald|first=Ben|work=The Sun|date=March 19, 2015|accessdate=March 9, 2017}} [[Image:Hacksaw-Jim-Duggan-Entrance,-RLA-Melb-10.11.2007 filtered.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Duggan post-match]] In November 2018, Duggan was hospitalized in the [[intensive care unit]] for an undisclosed reason.{{cite web|url=https://thesportsdaily.com/2018/11/23/wwe-hall-of-famer-hacksaw-jim-duggan-hospitalized-in-intensive-care-unit-tfs1102/|title=WWE Hall Of Famer 'Hacksaw' Jim Duggan Hospitalized In Intensive Care Unit|publisher=The Sports Daily|accessdate=November 24, 2018|date=November 24, 2018}} == Championships and accomplishments == [[Image:Robdog hacksaw.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Duggan (right) posing with a fan]] *'''[[George Tragos/Lou Thesz Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame]]''' **Frank Gotch Award (2011){{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.com/Slam/Wrestling/2010/11/15/16159286.html|title=Tragos/Thesz HOF to honour Funk Jr., Monsoon, Ross, Duggan|last=Oliver|first=Greg|website=Slam! revision.comment: Difference between a restrictive and non-restrictive modifying phrase
revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''Lacrimae rerum''''' ({{IPA-la|ˈlakrimai ˈreːrum|lang}}{{Cite web |url=http://www.m-w.com/dictionary/rerum |title=lacrimae rerum |work=Merriam-Webster Online Dictionary |publisher=[[Merriam-Webster]] |accessdate=2007-12-20 }} The words themselves are from ''lacrima, -ae'', a first declension noun meaning "tear" (appearing here in the nominative plural) and from ''res, rei'' a fifth declension noun meaning "thing" (appearing here in the genitive plural). ) is the [[Latin]] phrase for "tears of things." It derives from Book I, line 462 of the ''[[Aeneid]]'' (c. 29–19 BC), by Roman poet [[Virgil]] (Publius Vergilius Maro) (70–19 BC). Some recent quotations have included ''rerum lacrimae sunt'' or ''sunt lacrimae rerum'' meaning "there are tears of (or for) things." ==Background== In this passage, [[Aeneas]] gazes at a mural found in a [[Religion in Carthage|Carthaginian temple]] dedicated to [[Juno (mythology)|Juno]] that depicts battles of the [[Trojan War]] and the deaths of his friends and countrymen. Aeneas is moved to tears and says "sunt lacrimae rerum et mentem mortalia tangunt" ("There are tears for [or 'of'] things and mortal things touch the mind.") ==Two interpretations== The [[Genitive case|genitive]] "rerum" can be construed as "objective" or "subjective." The scholar David Wharton observes that the "semantic and referential indeterminacy is both intentional and poetically productive, lending it an implicational richness most readers find attractive." {{sfnb|Wharton|2008|p=259}} In English, however, a translator must choose either one or the other, and interpretation has varied. Those who take the genitive as ''subjective'' translate the phrase as meaning that things feel sorrow for the sufferings of humanity: the universe feels our pain. Others translate the passage to show that the burden human beings have to bear, ever present frailty and suffering, is what defines the essence of human experience. Yet in the next line, Aeneas says: "Release (your) fear; this fame will bring you some deliverance." Those who take the genitive as ''objective'' understand the phrase as meaning that there are tears ''for'' things (in particular, the things Aeneas has endured) evinced in the mural: i.e., the paintings show Aeneas that he finds himself in a place where he can expect compassion and safety. ==Context and translations== The context of the passage is as follows: Aeneas sees on the temple mural depictions of key figures in the Trojan War – the war from which he had been driven to the alien shores of Carthage as a refugee: the sons of Atreus (Agamemnon and Menelaus), Priam, and Achilles, who was savage to both sides in the war. He then cries out:
"Sunt hic etiam sua praemia laudi; sunt lacrimae rerum et mentem mortalia tangunt. Solve metus; feret haec aliquam tibi fama salutem." "Here, too, the praiseworthy has its rewards; there are tears for things and mortal things touch the mind. Release your fear; this fame will bring you some safety." Virgil, ''Aeneid'', 1.461 ff.
A translation by [[Robert Fagles]] renders the quote as: "The world is a world of tears, and the burdens of mortality touch the heart."Willard Spiegelman, ''Imaginative transcripts: selected literary essays'', Oxford Univ. Press, p.11 [[Robert Fitzgerald]], meanwhile, translates it as: "They weep here / For how the world goes, and our life that passes \ Touches their hearts."Nicolae Babuts, ''Memory, metaphors, and meaning: reading literary texts'', Transaction Publishers, 2009, p.173 In his television series [[Civilisation (TV series)|Civilisation]], episode 1, [[Kenneth Clark]] translated this line as "These men know the pathos of life, and mortal things touch their hearts."https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PNGzoJFj9g8 The poet [[Seamus Heaney]] rendered the first three words, "There are tears at the heart of things."Seamus Heaney, ''Virgil's Poetic Influence'', an essay broadcast on [[BBC Radio 3]] as part of the Greek and Latin Voices series, 15 July, 2008 (23:00). ==Usage== The phrase is sometimes taken out of context, on war memorials for example, as a sad sentiment about life's inescapable sorrows. In the poem the phrase appears as Aeneas realises that he need not fear for his safety, because he is among people who have compassion and an understanding of human sorrow. ==See also== * [[Pathos]] * [[Mono no aware]] * [[Weltschmerz]] ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== {{cite journal |last =Wharton |first =David |authorlink = |title =Sunt Lacrimae Rerum: An Exploration in Meaning |journal =The Classical Journal |volume = 103|issue = 3|pages =259–279 |publisher = |location = |date =2008 |language = |jstor= 30037962 |issn = |doi = |accessdate = |ref= harv }} ==External links== *[http://www.thelatinlibrary.com/vergil/aen1.shtml ''Aeneid'' Book I at The Latin Library] {{Aeneid}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lacrimae Rerum}} [[Category:Latin words and phrases]] [[Category:Words and phrases with no direct English translation]]

The '''National Technical Reports Library''' (NTRL) was created by the [[National Technical Information Service]] (NTIS), an agency of the [[United States Department of Commerce|U.S. Department of Commerce]], as a means of disseminating scientific and technical information produced by federal and international sources.
The NTRL is an IP-authenticated subscription-based platform which allows subscribers to search the extensive NTIS collection using bibliographic parameters. The NTRL is a useful tool for members of the business, library, government, and academic communities as it provides a solution to locating the results of billions of dollars of federal research on a wide variety of topics, including Aeronautics, Chemistry, Energy, Environment, [[Health care|Health Care]], Library & [[Information science|Information Sciences]], Mathematics, Medicine & Biology, Physics, and Transportation. These are only some of the numerous subjects covered by the NTRL.
The NTRL is an overarching means of accessing over 3 million bibliographic records and over 800K full-text reports. Searching of documents is available on the Internet for free. Some documents can be downloaded from the website, but the vast majority of the holdings are only available by subscription.
==External links== *[[National Technical Information Service]] [http://www.ntis.gov/] *National Technical Reports Library [https://ntrl.ntis.gov/NTRL/] *[[United States Department of Commerce]] [http://www.commerce.gov/]
